articles.headline: U.S. Drops ‘Mother of All Bombs’ on ISIS Caves in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A new version of the most powerful conventional bomb in the American arsenal, so big it had to be dropped from a cargo plane, was used for the first time in combat.
articles.abstract: A new version of the most powerful conventional bomb in the American arsenal, so big it had to be dropped from a cargo plane, was used for the first time in combat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States dropped the “mother of all bombs” — the most powerful conventional bomb in the American arsenal — on an Islamic State cave complex in Afghanistan on Thursday, the Pentagon said, unleashing a weapon so massive that it had to be dropped from the rear of a cargo plane.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: Ford Foundation Is an Unlikely Convert to ‘Impact’ Investing
articles.snippet: Breaking with orthodoxy, the organization says it can produce both solid returns and social good with its portfolio and urges others to follow.
articles.abstract: Breaking with orthodoxy, the organization says it can produce both solid returns and social good with its portfolio and urges others to follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter A. Nadosy is a pillar of the Wall Street establishment — he spent 27 years at Morgan Stanley, rising to vice chairman. He served a stint managing the endowment at Harvard, his alma mater, and he’s also a life trustee and member of the investment committee at Amherst College. He’s on multiple boards of nonprofit institutions, including the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation and St. Andrew’s Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

articles.headline: United and Pepsi Affairs Force Brands to Respect Social Media
articles.snippet: The potential perils that come with broad access to consumers have led companies to take it very seriously.
articles.abstract: The potential perils that come with broad access to consumers have led companies to take it very seriously.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jason Marker, the new chief executive of the company that owns Carl’s Jr. and Hardee’s, met with several of his marketing executives this week, one of his first requests was for screens to be installed in the company’s headquarters to display real-time social media conversations about its brands.

articles.headline: Trump Threatens Health Subsidies to Force Democrats to Bargain
articles.snippet: The president’s tone differs from that of Republicans in Congress, who have repeatedly promised a smooth transition away from the law they call Obamacare.
articles.abstract: The president’s tone differs from that of Republicans in Congress, who have repeatedly promised a smooth transition away from the law they call Obamacare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the weeks since President Trump’s attempts to replace the Affordable Care Act collapsed, the administration has debated what to do: Try again? Shore up the insurance marketplaces? Or let the whole system collapse?

articles.headline: Bank Lending Stalls on Doubts About Trump’s Pro-Growth Agenda
articles.snippet: A slowdown in bank lending is the latest indication that Wall Street is giving a sober assessment to the feasibility of the growth-focused Trump agenda.
articles.abstract: A slowdown in bank lending is the latest indication that Wall Street is giving a sober assessment to the feasibility of the growth-focused Trump agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many business owners and corporate executives have expressed unbridled optimism that President Trump can fuel economic growth and increase their profits.

articles.headline: For Trump, a Steep Learning Curve Leads to Policy Reversals
articles.snippet: President Trump, the first occupant of the White House never to serve in government or the military, discovers some issues are more complex than he knew.
articles.abstract: President Trump, the first occupant of the White House never to serve in government or the military, discovers some issues are more complex than he knew.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump, the road to changing his mind on China included a discussion with corporate executives in the State Dining Room of the White House in February. When the conversation turned to China’s currency, the executives had a simple message for the president: You’re wrong.

articles.headline: Le Pen’s Inner Circle Fuels Doubt About Bid to ‘Un-Demonize’ Her Party
articles.snippet: Two of the French candidate’s associates have longtime links to Nazi sympathizers and have been central to the National Front’s campaign finance scandals.
articles.abstract: Two of the French candidate’s associates have longtime links to Nazi sympathizers and have been central to the National Front’s campaign finance scandals.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Little more than a week before France’s presidential election, Marine Le Pen remains a front-runner after working hard to sanitize the image of her party, the National Front, and to distance it from the uglier associations of Europe’s far right.

articles.headline: As New Zealand Courts Tech Talent, Isolation Becomes a Draw
articles.snippet: A program to offer developers jobs was flooded with more than 48,000 applications as many in the field look for distance from the political polarization in the United States and Europe.
articles.abstract: A program to offer developers jobs was flooded with more than 48,000 applications as many in the field look for distance from the political polarization in the United States and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — In the South Pacific, software no longer needs a hard sell.
articles.byline: By Jacqueline Williams and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Siege Has Ended, but Battle Over Public Lands Rages On
articles.snippet: A year after the armed occupation of a federal wildlife refuge, new and old players wage battle over what and whom the lands are for.
articles.abstract: A year after the armed occupation of a federal wildlife refuge, new and old players wage battle over what and whom the lands are for.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — A year ago, this corner of rural Oregon became center stage in the drawn-out drama over public lands when armed militia leaders seized a national wildlife refuge, arguing that the government had too much control of land in the West.

articles.headline: A Baby or Your Money Back: All About Fertility Clinic Package Deals
articles.snippet: In the high-stakes casino of fertility treatment, some pay large sums upfront for the promise of a baby — or a refund. Doctors tend to pick patients with the best odds of success.
articles.abstract: In the high-stakes casino of fertility treatment, some pay large sums upfront for the promise of a baby — or a refund. Doctors tend to pick patients with the best odds of success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to have a baby with the aid of modern reproductive technology can feel like visiting a gambling parlor with the highest possible stakes. So consider the pitch that many fertility clinics now put in front of people like Kristi and Carleton Chambers.

articles.headline: China Warns of ‘Storm Clouds Gathering’ in U.S.-North Korea Standoff
articles.snippet: Beijing urged an end to “mutual provocation and threats,” cautioning that tensions on the Korean Peninsula could run out of control.
articles.abstract: Beijing urged an end to “mutual provocation and threats,” cautioning that tensions on the Korean Peninsula could run out of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China warned on Friday that tensions on the Korean Peninsula could spin out of control, as North Korea said it could test a nuclear weapon at any time and a United States naval group neared the peninsula — an American effort to sow doubt in Pyongyang over how President Trump might respond.
articles.byline: By Gerry Mullany, Chris Buckley and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Uber Wants to Rule the World. First It Must Conquer India.
articles.snippet: Uber is diving headlong into India, where it must face the sobering realities of analog life in a rapidly developing country.
articles.abstract: Uber is diving headlong into India, where it must face the sobering realities of analog life in a rapidly developing country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — Nandini Balasubramanya’s office here on the southern edge of India’s technology capital does not look as if it would play a key role in the world’s most valuable start-up’s plans for global conquest.
